heading: cisco strikes back
subheading: the network-hardware vendor responds to lucent's acquisition of ascend with a few juicy tidbits about a superfast new routing architecture. details are scant so far. by joanna glasner.
author: joanna glasner
text: facing even bigger rivals than before, cisco systems is getting ready to introduce a fast system for routing all kinds of traffic over a single network. the world's largest computer-network hardware vendor said its new system, based on a device called the virtual switch controller, will let communications carriers send voice, video, and data traffic through public or private networks. the company plans to begin marketing the service to internet service providers, telcos, and big companies in about two months.cisco's (csco) disclosure of its latest product launch comes less than two weeks after its biggest rival, lucent technologies, agreed to acquire another rival, ascend communications. some saw cisco's product plans as a mild response."as a comeback to lucent buying ascend, it doesn't sound like much of a cap gun," said steve kelly, vice president and co-founder of castle networks, a start-up that develops switching technology for voice and data traffic. "it telegraphs the message that, 'clearly, we're not going to join these guys.'"cisco and lucent are racing to create a single networking device that can route computer data, telephone calls, and video through global telecommunications networks. ascend (asnd), which lucent is buying for about us$20 billion, specializes in routers and carrier-class switches for large corporate and public telecom networks.besides lucent, cisco faces a host of other competitors looking to build new voice-and-data networks, including siemens, nortel networks, and ericsson. a number of start-ups are developing technology in the field, too.technical details of the new system are so far scant, and cisco officials said the company is still working on beta versions of the new system. but a spokesman said the new routing architecture will be far faster than previous incarnations. it even will be fast enough to handle traffic on a traditional telephone network."my guess is that this isn't even the beginning of the cisco response to lucent buying ascend," kelly said.
